Previous Next

netsquid.qubits.stabtools

Tools for manipulating quantum stabilizer states, one of the available formalisms for shared quantum states held by qubits.

class netsquid.qubits.stabtools.StabRepr(check_matrix=None, phases=None, destab_matrix=None, num_qubits=None)

Bases: QRepr

Representation of a quantum state using a check matrix and phases array.

The check matrix G represents the set of \(n\) generators \(G_i\) that stabilize our quantum state, i.e. \(G_i \vert \phi \rangle = P_i \vert \phi \rangle\), where \(P\) is our phases array containing 1 or -1. Each row of the check matrix is a generator where the first \(n\) elements indicate if an \(X\) literal is present, and the second n elements if a \(Z\) literal is present. If both are present this equals a \(Y\) literal and if none are present an \(I\) literal. See the examples section for a few common states shown in this format.

Additionally to the check matrix and the phases array a destabilizer array is used. It is used to speed up deterministic measurements. For more information see this paper.

Parameters:

  • check_matrix (2D-array_like, optional) – An object that can be cast into a \((n, 2n)\) matrix with values of 0 or 1.

  • phases (1D-array_like, optional) – An object that can be cast into an array of length \(n\) with values of \(\pm 1\). Required if check_matrix is given.

  • destab_matrix (2D-array_like, optional) – An object that can be cast into a \((n, 2n)\) matrix. Will be calculated if not provided, this is an expensive operation.

  • num_qubits (int, optional) – The number of qubits of this qstate. Only used if check_matrix is None.

Raises:

TypeError – If the number of qubits given is not an integer.

supports_universal

A class attribute indicating this class does not support universal quantum computation.

Type:

bool

supports_mixed_states

A class attribute indicating this class does not support mixed quantum states.

Type:

bool

Examples

>>> from netsquid.qubits.stabtools import StabRepr

The default quantum state is the \(\vert 0 ... 0 \rangle\) state, and can be created by specifying the number of qubits.

>>> stab1 = StabRepr(num_qubits=1)
>>> stab1
StabRepr(num_qubits=1, check_matrix=
array([[0, 1]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([1], dtype=int8))

It is also possible to specify the state the qrepr should be initialized in.

>>> stab2 = StabRepr(check_matrix=[[1, 0]], phases=[1])
>>> stab2
StabRepr(num_qubits=1, check_matrix=
array([[1, 0]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([1], dtype=int8))

Operations will return a new qrepr by default.

>>> stab_out, m, p = stab2.measure(index=0)
>>> m  
0
>>> p
0.5
>>> stab_out  
StabRepr(num_qubits=1, check_matrix=
array([[0, 1]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([1], dtype=int8))

>>> stab2
StabRepr(num_qubits=1, check_matrix=
array([[1, 0]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([1], dtype=int8))

If an inplace operation is desired, the modify parameter can be set to True.

>>> stab_out, m, p = stab2.measure(index=0, modify=True)
>>> stab_out is stab2
True
>>> stab2  
StabRepr(num_qubits=1, check_matrix=
array([[0, 1]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([-1], dtype=int8))
check_matrix

The matrix representing the generators of this state.

Type:

ndarray

static create_in_basis(list basis_indices, basis_operator=ops.Z)

Create a representation in a given basis and with given eigenvalues.

Parameters:

  • basis_indices (list of int) – A list containing indices of the eigenkets of the basis_operator.

  • basis_operator (netsquid.qubits.operators.Operator, optional) – A single qubit observable that defines the basis of the qubits. Default the computational (Z) basis.

Returns:

The representation of this state.

Return type:

StabRepr

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the list of eigenvalues is emtpy. If the operator is not a single qubit observable.

  • IndexError – If an index indexes beyond the available eigenkets of the operator.

  • TypeError – If the basis_operator is not of type Operator.

  • NotImplementedError – If any clifford operator other than X, Y or Z is used.

Examples

To quickly make 2 qubits in the X basis:

>>> from netsquid import X
>>> StabRepr.create_in_basis([0, 1], X)
StabRepr(num_qubits=2, check_matrix=
array([[1, 0, 0, 0],
       [0, 1, 0, 0]], dtype=uint8),
phases=
array([ 1, -1], dtype=int8))
destab_matrix

The matrix representing the destabilizers of this state.

Type:

ndarray

discard(self, int index) → QRepr

Discard the qubit at the index.

Parameters:

index (int) – Index of the qubit to drop from the quantum state.

Returns:

The representation of the state.

Return type:

StabRepr

fidelity(self, QRepr reference_state, indices=None, bool squared=False) → double

Calculate the fidelity between this quantum state and a reference representation.

Parameters:

  • reference_state (QRepr) – A representation of a quantum state.

  • indices (list or tuple of int or None, optional) – The indices that should be used in the fidelity calculations. Default: the entire state.

  • squared (bool, optional) – If True the squared fidelity is returned. Default False.

Returns:

Fidelity (or squared fidelity).

Return type:

float

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If length of reference ket does not match number of qubits in this ket state. If the dimensions of the reference state don’t match a KET or DM state

  • TypeError – If the provided reference state is not of type QRepr.

generator_to_matrix(self, Py_ssize_t row_index)

Convert a generator row to its full matrix representation.

Parameters:

row_index (int) – Row index of generator.

Returns:

Matrix operator representation of generator row.

Return type:

numpy.array

gmeasure(self, indices, operators, rng=None, bool modify=False) → tuple

Measure at the indices with the operators.

This method is implemented only for pauli operators, and requires the operators to be provided as a single Operator, built from the pauli operators tensored together.

Parameters:

  • indices (int, list or tuple of int) – The indices to measure at.

  • operators (list (or tuple) of Operator or Operator) – List of measurement operators with which to measure, or a single Hermitian observable, i.e. an operator with valid projectors.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

  • StabRepr – The representation of the state after applying the measurement.

  • int – The measurement result.

  • float – The probability of finding the measurement result.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If a operator doesn’t match the number of qubits.

  • RuntimeError – If no measurement operator has succeeded.

  • TypeError – If the operator is not a pauli operator.

  • NotImplementedError – If the operators are given as a list of measurement operators.

is_valid

If the representation matches all its constraints. Can be an expensive operation.

Type:

bool

log_operation(self, opname)

Log and count a quantum state operation.

Parameters:

opname (str) – Name of the operation.

measure(self, int index, observable=ops.Z, rng=None, bool modify=False) → tuple

Measure at the index with the observable.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index to measure at.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – The observable with which to measure. Default the computational (Z) basis.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

  • StabRepr – The representation of the state after applying the measurement.

  • int – The measurement result.

  • float – The probability of finding the measurement result.

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If the observable is not Hermitian.

measure_discard(self, int index, observable=ops.Z, rng=None) → tuple

Measure at the index in a particular basis and discard it from this state.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index to act at.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – The observable to measure the qubit with. Default the computational (Z) basis.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

Returns:

  • StabRepr – The representation of the state after applying the operation.

  • int – Measurement result

  • float – Probability of measuring the result

Notes

Intended to be a more efficient method than just measuring and then discarding.

multi_operate(self, indices, operators, weights=None, rng=None, bool modify=False) → QRepr

Apply a (weighted) list of quantum operators to a list of qubits.

This method is not implemented since not all output states are supported by this representation.

Parameters:

  • indices (list or tuple of int) – The indices to operate at.

  • operators (list or tuple of Operator) – The operators with which to measure

  • weights (list or tuple of float or None, optional) – Weights for each operator. The default (None) is for each operator to have a weight of 1.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

The representation of the state after applying the operations.

Return type:

StabRepr

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation If not all given indices are unique If a operator doesn’t match the number of qubits

Notes

If the operation results in a mixed states a sample will be taken.

multiply_rows(self, mult_index, target_index)

Multiply a target generator row using another generator row.

The target generator is modified inplace. For multiplier m and target t, the result it t -> m * t.

Parameters:

  • mult_index (int) – Index of row corresponding to generator to multiply with.

  • target_index (int) – Index of row corresponding to the generator to multiply.

num_qubits

The number of qubits this representation represents.

Type:

int

operate(self, indices, operator, bool modify=False) → QRepr

Operate on the qubits at the indices with the operator

Parameters:

  • indices (list or tuple of int) – The indices to operate at.

  • operator (Operator) – The operator with which to act.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

The representation of the state after applying the operation.

Return type:

StabRepr

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation If not all given indices are unique If the number of indices doesn’t match the operator

phases

The array representing the phases associated with the generators.

Type:

ndarray

reduced_dm(self, indices=None) → ndarray

Returns the reduced density matrix for the given indices.

This is the result of discarding all other indices.

Parameters:

indices (list or tuple of int or None, optional) – The selection of qubits to find the reduced state for. The order of the indices will define the vector space for the reduced state. Default the whole state.

Returns:

Density matrix representing the reduced density matrix.

Return type:

numpy.array

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique.

Notes

Uses |psi><psi| = prod(k=1..N) (I + g_k)/2 for generators g_k.

row_reduce(self)

Perform inplace Gaussian elimination on the check matrix and phases.

smart_tensor(self, QRepr other, bool force_append=True) → tuple

Combine the data of this representation and another one.

In order to optimize the tensor product the order of the tensor product can be reversed.

Parameters:

  • other (QRepr) – Another representation of a quantum state.

  • force_append (bool) – If the optimizations must be disabled and other must be appended to self.

Returns:

  • QRepr – A new instance that combines the two representations.

  • bool – True if the order was changed, i.e. if other was prepended to self instead of appended.

Raises:

TypeError – If the representations to combine are not of the same type.

tensor(self, QRepr other) → QRepr

Combine the data of this representation and another one.

The tensor operation is also possible via the ^ operator.

Parameters:

other (QRepr) – Another representation of a quantum state.

Returns:

A new instance that combines the two representations.

Return type:

QRepr

to_basis_state(self, bool normalize_phases=False)

Transform the state into the standard basis and return the gates that were used.

The standard basis is represented by the state with generators I..IZI..I and phases either +1 or -1. The list of gates that are returned is in the order of application, thus applying their inverse in reverse will restore the original state, up to some row multiplications/swaps.

Parameters:

normalize_phases (bool, optional) – If True X gates are used to normalize the phases to +1. Default False.

Returns:

A list containing tuples of operators with indices.

Return type:

list

Notes

The returned set of gates is by no means optimal. The returned structure is H-CNOT-CPHASE(CZ)-P-H with additional X gates if normalize_phases is set to True. The algorithm is provided by Garcia et al, Algorithm 2.

netsquid.qubits.stabtools.clifford_transform(operator, pauli_indices, bool cache=True)

Transform a Pauli group element with this operator.

Assumes this is a Clifford operator, so that the result is also a Pauli group element.

Parameters:

  • operator (Operator) – Operator to transform pauli group element with.

  • pauli_indices (tuple of ints) – Tuple of indices, where each index specifies a Pauli operator of the Pauli group element to be transformed.

    Index

    Pauli operator

    0

    I

    1

    Z

    2

    X

    3

    Y

    For example, the Pauli group element \(X\otimes Y \otimes Z \otimes I\) is represented by the tuple (2, 3, 1, 0).

  • cache (bool, optional) – Whether to cache the resulting pauli element for faster lookup next time it is needed. Requires that operator is also cacheable.

Returns:

  • array of ints – Array of indices, where each index specifies a Pauli operator of the resulting Pauli group element.

  • int – Phase of new Pauli group element relative to the phase of the input element.

Raises:

ValueError – If this is not a valid Clifford operator.

Notes

Computing the actions of this operator on Pauli group elements is generally expensive. Using the caching option can therefore significantly speed up simulations. Caching can be disabled globally by setting caching_enabled to False.
